skill.name: Backend API
skill.description: Design and implement RESTful API endpoints following REST principles, HTTP standards, and resource-based URL conventions. Use this skill when creating or modifying API endpoints, routes, controllers, request handlers, or API documentation. Apply when working with REST API design, API versioning, HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE), URL structure, query parameters, response formatting, status codes, rate limiting, or API middleware. Use when building web services, microservices, or any backend code that exposes HTTP endpoints for client consumption.

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation with no executable code. The skill provides guidance for AI assistants on backend API design patterns and does not access filesystem, network, environment variables, or execute external commands.

content.value_statement: Building APIs without consistent standards leads to confusing interfaces and maintenance challenges. This skill provides structured guidance for designing RESTful APIs that follow industry best practices for URL structure, HTTP methods, status codes, and versioning.
actual_capabilities: Design resource-based URL structures following REST conventions
Implement proper HTTP method usage (GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE)
Handle HTTP status codes and response formatting correctly
Create API versioning strategies for backward compatibility
Build query parameter handling for filtering, sorting, pagination
Implement middleware for authentication, rate limiting, validation
limitations: Does not generate actual API code implementation
Does not connect to running servers or test endpoints
Does not validate existing API specifications
Provides guidance only - actual implementation requires development environment

prompt_templates.title: Basic Endpoint Design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a RESTful endpoint structure for a [RESOURCE_NAME] resource with standard CRUD operations

prompt_templates.title: Query Parameters
prompt_templates.prompt: How should I implement query parameters for filtering, sorting, and pagination on a GET /[RESOURCE] endpoint?

prompt_templates.title: Versioning Strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: What's the best approach for versioning a REST API when adding new features without breaking existing clients?

prompt_templates.title: Error Handling
prompt_templates.prompt: Design an error response format and appropriate HTTP status codes for validation errors, authentication failures, and resource not found scenarios

output_examples.input: Design a RESTful API structure for a user management system
output: GET /users - List all users with optional filtering
GET /users/{id} - Retrieve a specific user by ID
PUT /users/{id} - Update an existing user completely
Use 200 for success, 201 for creation, 204 for deletion with no content
Use 400 for bad request, 401 for unauthorized, 403 for forbidden, 404 for not found

best_practices: Use plural nouns for resource names (e.g., /users not /user)
Use nested resources for hierarchical relationships (e.g., /users/{id}/posts)
Return appropriate HTTP status codes for all response scenarios
anti_patterns: Using verbs in URLs instead of nouns (/getUsers instead of /users)
Mixing singular and plural resource names inconsistently
Returning 200 OK for all responses including errors

faq.question: Should I use path or query parameters for filtering?
faq.answer: Use path parameters for resource identification and query parameters for filtering, sorting, and pagination.

faq.question: What is the difference between PUT and PATCH?
faq.answer: PUT replaces a resource entirely while PATCH modifies only specified fields. Use PUT for full updates and PATCH for partial updates.

faq.question: How should I handle API versioning?
faq.answer: Common approaches include URL path versioning (/v1/users) or header versioning. URL path is simpler for documentation and client usage.

faq.question: What status code should I use for authentication errors?
faq.answer: Use 401 Unauthorized when credentials are missing or invalid. Use 403 Forbidden when the user is authenticated but lacks permission.

faq.question: How do I implement rate limiting in a REST API?
faq.answer: Use headers like X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, and X-RateLimit-Reset. Return 429 Too Many Requests when limits are exceeded.

faq.question: Should API responses include nested related resources?
faq.answer: Keep responses flat when possible. Use include parameters or separate endpoints for related resources to avoid over-fetching.
